title: Supreme Court Blocks Trump's Bid to Dismiss Fed's Cook Amid Fraud Claims
snippets: The Supreme Court has temporarily blocked President Trump's attempt to fire Federal Reserve governor Lisa Cook, a move that critics say would have compromised the central bank's independence
Supreme Court says Fed governor Cook can remain in job pending arguments &
President Donald Trump has sought to fire Federal Reserve Governor Lisa Cook, citing claims that she committed mortgage fraud in connection with two homes.
Court’s announcement means Lisa Cook will remain in the post for now, despite first-ever bid by a president to fire a Fed official
titles: Supreme Court says Federal Reserve Governor Lisa Cook can stay -- for now
Supreme Court says Fed governor Cook can remain in job pending arguments - Axios
Supreme Court lets Fed Governor Lisa Cook keep job pending oral argument in January
Federal reserve governor will stay in post for now following US supreme court announcement
summary: The Supreme Court has temporarily halted President Trump's attempt to dismiss Federal Reserve Governor Lisa Cook, amidst allegations of mortgage fraud. This decision preserves the central bank's independence for now and marks a significant moment as it's the first instance of a president attempting to fire a Fed official. Cook will maintain her position pending further court deliberations.

title: Oktoberfest Reopens After Closure Due to Bomb Threat Linked to Domestic Dispute
snippets: The annual beer festival was closed for several hours because of possible links to an explosion and fire.

Germany's world-famous Oktoberfest beer festival will open again on Wednesday evening, the city's mayor has said. A house fire and suspected suicide with a potential link to the event halted proceedings. DW has more.
Hours after a written threat, by a suspect who killed himself, authorities said the beer celebration would reopen after a search of the grounds found no explosives.
The German authorities said the decision to close the festival grounds was taken after an earlier explosion in a residential area of the city that appeared linked to a domestic dispute.

MUNICH (AP) — German police completed a security sweep at the Oktoberfest fairgrounds and said the famed beer festival was reopening after an hourslong closure due to a bomb threat by a suspect linked to an explosion Wednesday across town in northern Munich. Police in Bavaria, the state where Munich
titles: Munich Oktoberfest to re-open after fatal house fire and bomb threat
Germany news: Oktoberfest set to reopen after bomb scare
Oktoberfest in Munich cleared to reopen after bomb threat
Bomb Threat Delays Oktoberfest in Munich
Police say security sweep ends and Oktoberfest is reopening after bomb threat
summary: The Oktoberfest beer festival in Munich, Germany, was temporarily closed due to a bomb threat linked to an explosion and fire in a residential area, suspected to be connected to a domestic dispute. The threat came from a suspect who later committed suicide. After a thorough security sweep of the festival grounds revealed no explosives, authorities announced the event would reopen on Wednesday evening. The closure was a precautionary measure to ensure public safety.

title: New Jersey Devils Sign Luke Hughes to $63M, 7-Year Deal

Luke Hughes was one of just a couple restricted free agents left unsigned with opening night just about a week away.

Luke Hughes signs 7-year, $63 million contract with Devils - NHL.com
Luke Hughes signs seven-year, $63-million deal with Devils
summary: The New Jersey Devils have signed defenseman Luke Hughes to a $63 million, seven-year contract. Hughes, 22, was one of the few remaining restricted free agents. This deal secures the franchise defenseman just ahead of the season's start.

title: U.S. Government Shuts Down Amid Congressional Deadlock
snippets: The federal government has shut down for the first time since 2019. Mass layoffs have been threatened. And, President Trump announced a pricing deal with Pfizer.
Funding has been cut off after Republicans and Democrats failed to agree a way forward on a spending bill.
Hundreds of thousands federal employees to be furloughed while others, including FBI, CIA agents, will work without pay.
The US Government has shut down after the Senate failed to pass a spending bill. Heidi Zhou Castro breaks it down.

The US government has officially shut down after lawmakers couldn't agree on a funding deal. Who is impacted when the government can't pay its bills? Could the Trump administration use it as an excuse for more layoffs?
titles: What happens now that the government has shut down. And, a pricing deal with Pfizer
Why the US government has shut down and what happens now
The US government has shut down – what happens now?
What happens when the US government shuts down?
US government shutdown: What happens and who's affected?
summary: The U.S. federal government officially shut down at 12:01 a.m. Wednesday due to a deadlock in Congress over spending bills. This marks the first government shutdown since 2019. Amidst the shutdown, President Trump announced a pricing deal with Pfizer. The shutdown threatens mass layoffs unless resolved.

title: Supreme Court Delays Trump vs. Cook Fed Decision to 2026
snippets: Justices defer decision on president’s bid to sack central banker until January 2026
If Trump can oust Lisa Cook, he could have majority control of the Federal Reserve.
Cook will remain at the Federal Reserve until the Supreme Court hears oral arguments from the Trump administration in January.
The White House has been trying to fire Cook since late August, with Trump and his allies arguing that she engaged in mortgage fraud in loan documents she signed before she joined the Fed in 2022.
titles: Supreme Court blocks Trump from immediately firing Fed’s Lisa Cook
Supreme Court puts off decision on whether Trump may fire Federal Reserve Governor Lisa Cook
Supreme Court Won’t Let Trump Fire Lisa Cook—For Now
Supreme Court allows Lisa Cook to stay on at Fed, for now. What’s next as Trump tries to fire her.
summary: The Supreme Court has postponed its decision on whether President Trump can fire Federal Reserve member Lisa Cook to January 2026. Cook, accused by Trump of mortgage fraud prior to her 2022 Fed appointment, will stay in her position until then. Trump's success in removing Cook could grant him majority control over the Federal Reserve.

title: 6.9 Earthquake in Philippines Kills 60, Injures 140 in Cebu and Bogo
snippets: The earthquake comes barely more than a week after the country was hit by back-to-back typhoons.
Injured patients have overwhelmed the main hospital in Bogo city where children and adults were seen screaming while receiving treatment in the driveway.
A 6.9-magnitude earthquake struck the central Philippines, damaging numerous businesses and leaving towns without power. Casualty numbers are expected to rise
The 6.9-magnitude earthquake shook the province of Cebu, killing at least 69 people and injuring more than 150. Heavy rainfall has hampered rescue efforts.
titles: State of calamity in Philippines province as earthquake kills 69
Philippines hit by 6.9 magnitude earthquake, dozens dead
Powerful earthquake in central Philippines kills at least 69
Earthquake in Philippines Kills Dozens, Officials Say
summary: A magnitude 6.9 earthquake hit central Philippines, affecting the province of Cebu and the coastal city of Bogo, resulting in at least 60 deaths and over 140 injuries, according to a civil defence official. The quake caused widespread power outages, building and road damage, and hampered rescue operations due to heavy rainfall. Rescuers continue to search for survivors amidst the debris.

title: US Faces 10th Shutdown Since 1976, Air Travel May Suffer Delays
snippets: The US government has had 20 funding gaps, resulting in 10 shutdowns since 1976, the longest lasting 35 days.
The government shutdown could disrupt flights, extend security wait times, and slow safety functions, creating a stressful travel experience.

Air-traffic controllers and many Transportation Security Administration employees, including airport screeners, are classified as essential workers. That doesn’t mean that all air travel will be smooth.
titles: A history of US government shutdowns: Every closure and how long it lasted
How the US government shutdown could impact your next flight
How the government shutdown and TSA could delay your flight
summary: Since 1976, the US has experienced 20 funding gaps, leading to 10 government shutdowns, with the longest lasting 35 days. A shutdown could disrupt air travel, causing longer security wait times and impacting safety functions, despite air-traffic controllers and TSA screeners being classified as essential workers.

title: UK Orders Apple for iCloud Access Again Amid Privacy Dispute
snippets: It is the latest development in a privacy row which has pitted the UK against the tech giant and the Trump administration.
Order issued in September comes after Trump administration said London had backed down in fight over encryption
The U.K. Home Office is seeking access to Apple users’ encrypted iCloud backups for a second time, after an earlier attempt failed earlier this year.
titles: Government issues new data demand for UK Apple users
UK makes new attempt to access Apple cloud data
UK government tries again to access encrypted Apple customer data: report
summary: The U.K. Home Office has issued a second order for access to Apple users' encrypted iCloud backups, following a failed attempt earlier this year. This action is part of an ongoing privacy dispute involving the UK, the tech giant, and the Trump administration. The controversy escalated after the Trump administration claimed that London had conceded in a battle over encryption.

title: Ex-Congo President Kabila Sentenced to Death in Absentia for Multiple Crimes
snippets: A military court in the Democratic Republic of the Congo has sentenced ex-President Joseph Kabila to death in absentia.

Military court convicts Kabila of war crimes, treason and other offences in verdict that could fuel enduring tensions

A military court in the Democratic Republic of the Congo has sentenced the country’s former president Joseph Kabila to death in absentia after convicting him of war crimes,
Joseph Kabila, who was president of the Democratic Republic of Congo for 18 years, was convicted of treason by a court in Kinshasa.
titles: Why was former DR Congo president Kabila sentenced to death?
Former DRC president Joseph Kabila sentenced to death in absentia
Congo’s Former President Sentenced to Death in Absentia
summary: Former Congolese President Joseph Kabila was sentenced to death in absentia by a military court in the Democratic Republic of the Congo. He was convicted of several crimes, including treason, murder, torture, and complicity with the M23 militia. This verdict comes after Kabila's 18-year presidency and could escalate tensions in the region.

title: Indonesia School Collapse Kills 3, Injures 100 During Prayer
snippets: Indonesia's disaster management agency said at least six children are still alive under the rubble, as workers race against time to save lives.

Desperate search for more than 90 missing after building collapses while students held prayers at school in Sidoarjo

Parents and rescuers in Indonesia were desperately searching for dozens of teenage boys believed to be trapped, a day after the collapse of an Islamic boarding school which h
Workers rushed to free potential survivors two days after an Islamic boarding school collapsed during a prayer service, killing at least three students.
At least three children were killed and about 100 injured after an Islamic boarding school collapsed during a prayer service, officials said.
titles: Indonesia school collapse: Over 90 students still trapped
Indonesia school collapse: 91 missing and three dead as rescuers search rubble for second day
Time Running Out for Trapped Students After School Collapse in Indonesia
Dozens of Students Are Missing After School Collapses in Indonesia
summary: A school building in Indonesia collapsed during prayer time, resulting in at least three children dead and approximately 100 injured. The incident occurred at an Islamic boarding school. Rescue efforts were temporarily halted due to the risk of further collapse as authorities and rescuers work to find survivors and recover bodies.

snippets: Ottawa has denied a request from Marineland to send its remaining beluga whales to China, Fisheries Minister Joanne Thompson said Wednesday. The federal government will not grant an export permit to ship the 30 whales to the Chimelong Ocean Kingdom aquarium, she said. They are the last captive whale

Ottawa has denied a request from Marineland to send its remaining beluga whales to China. Fisheries Minister Joanne Thompson says the federal government will not grant an export permit to ship the 30 whales to the Chimelong Ocean Kingdom aquarium. Thompson says approving the request would mean a con
titles: Ottawa denies Marineland request to export its remaining beluga whales to China
Ottawa denies Marineland request to export its remaining beluga whales to China
summary: The Canadian government, through Fisheries Minister Joanne Thompson, has refused Marineland's request to export its last 30 captive beluga whales to Chimelong Ocean Kingdom aquarium in China. The federal government will not issue the necessary export permit for the transfer.

title: Browns Bench Flacco, Start Rookie Gabriel Against Vikings

Will making a move at quarterback turn the Browns' 2025 season around?

Browns to start Dillon Gabriel at QB, bench Joe Flacco after 1-3 start
summary: The Cleveland Browns have decided to bench Joe Flacco and will start rookie Dillon Gabriel as their quarterback for the upcoming Sunday game against the Minnesota Vikings. This change aims to address the team's performance in the 2025 season.

title: Braves Manager Brian Snitker Steps Down, Takes New Role After Playoff Miss
snippets: Brian Snitker, who guided the Braves to the 2021 World Series championship, will not return as manager after Atlanta failed to make the postseason for the first time since 2017.
The offseason carousel has started. Here's who is out -- and who could be in line to replace them.
With Brian Snitker deciding to step down as the Atlanta Braves manager and shift into another role with the organization, here are the best options for his replacement.
titles: Snitker won't return as Braves manager in 2026

summary: Brian Snitker, the manager who led the Braves to a 2021 World Series win, will not return as manager after the team missed the postseason for the first time since 2017. Snitker will take on a different role within the organization. The search for his replacement is underway.

title: UN Security Council Votes to Expand Haiti Mission with 5,500 Troops
snippets:
Unit will have up to 5,500 soldiers and police officers who will tackle the violence that has overwhelmed the country

The United Nations has adopted a resolution to transform a security mission in gang-dominated Haiti into a larger, fully fledged force with military troops.

The new un
The Security Council vote was an acknowledgment that the police mission it once backed had failed to wrest back control of the beleaguered Caribbean nation.
The vote on Tuesday would establish a force of up to 5,500 soldiers and police officers. It was unclear what countries were willing to contribute personnel or money.
titles: UN security council approves new military force to fight Haiti gangs
U.N. approves militarized force to take on Haiti’s gangs
U.N. Security Council Approves Larger Force to Fight Gangs in Haiti
summary: The United Nations Security Council has voted to expand a security mission in Haiti into a larger force with up to 5,500 soldiers and police officers. This decision aims to neutralize, isolate, and deter gangs that have overwhelmed the country. The move acknowledges the failure of the previous police mission to control the situation in Haiti. However, the contributing countries and funding details remain unspecified.

title: EU Plans $165B Loan for Ukraine Using Frozen Russian Assets

titles: EU leaders push to tap frozen Russian assets for Ukraine reconstruction
Moscow Indicates Retaliation if Europe Uses Russian Assets for Ukraine
summary: The EU, led by Kallas, is actively working on a $165 billion loan plan for Ukraine, aiming to utilize frozen Russian assets. European officials are considering the potential repercussions while discussing the proposal.

summary: The federal government shut down on Wednesday at midnight after Congress could not agree on a funding deal. This halt affects many government programs and services, with Democrats and Republicans unable to close the gap in negotiations.

title: Bill Schmidt Resigns as Rockies GM After Historic Losing Season
snippets: The Rockies won just 43 games in 2025.

Schmidt has been with the organization since 1999, including the last four seasons as general manager.  The Rockies turned in their third straight 100-loss sea
The Colorado Rockies announced Wednesday that general manager Bill Schmidt stepped down after one of the worst seasons in baseball history.
titles: Rockies general manager Bill Schmidt steps down after team posts worst record in franchise history
Rockies announce GM Bill Schmidt stepping down after one of worst seasons in MLB history
Rockies GM Bill Schmidt steps down after 119-loss season
summary: Bill Schmidt resigned as the general manager of the Colorado Rockies following a historically poor season, where the team won only 43 games. Schmidt, who had been with the organization since 1999 and served as GM for the last four years, stepped down after the Rockies' third consecutive 100-loss season.
